title: Huddle landing page
description: This was my first ever frontend mentor challenge. Looking back now, I can't describe how excited I was when I first found out about these challenges. It was also the start of one of my productive days as a learning web dev.

title: Blogr landing page
description: This was my second frontend mentor challenge. This one was particularly challenging to me because it involved working with background images which was quite new to me and I learned a lot from this one.

title: Tip Calculator
description: I remember vividly, I was halfway through CS50 WEB and I couldn't wait but skip to the JS lecture because I wanted to do some JS projects so badly. After that I came straight to this challenge. It took me more than 12 hours finish but it was definitely worth it.

title: NFT preview card
description: After my JS lecture, I started trying out more JS challenges, starting with this fairly simple one. This one took me quite a while to figure out how to write the CSS for the hover state of the image.

title: Advice generator
description: Not knowing exactly what an API is, I started this challenge anyway. I didn't know what async/await nor Promises were but I managed to implement the random advice generator API into this project through online help.

title: Chat app illustration
description: I was a CSS-enthusiast back then(it was what got me into web) and this was the perfect challenge for me to test my CSS skills. I also did another challenge on that same day which you can find in the next challenge below.

title: Pricing component with toggle
description: For this challenge, I wanted to try making a toggle button and the results were very rewarding. I also learned a trick to making a clean transition on the buttons with border without triggering any layout shifting.

title: Social media dashboard
description: Since I did the toggle button in the last challenge, I wanted to take it a step further and also implement dark/light mode. I started to note some accessibility issues I was having that I ignored before. As always, the results were incredibly rewarding and with a smooth transition, I couldn't stop pressing the toggle.

title: Time tracking dashboard
description: This was another one of those challenges for me to practice JS and CSS. I had so much trouble trying to figure out how to set a hover state on the child without setting it also on the parent which was impossible. I learned a trick called 'sibling trick' to achieve it.

title: E-commerce product page
description: This was one of the unexpectedly hard challenges I did. I took me more than 12 hours to complete. The image view especially was quite hard getting it the way I wanted. The styling was also a bit challening which made me question my CSS grid/flexbox skills and revisit those in depth.

title: Calculator app
description: This was one of my favorite challenges I did during my earlier days, especially the animations on the buttons were so satisfying. I also started experimenting with sounds in the challenge. For the calculator part, I just did what I thought was right and it was quite a mess but eventually I got it the way I wanted. I also plan to redo this challenge in the future to fill in some of the gaps and also add the keyboard support.

title: Room homepage
description: I wanted to try making a image slider for this challenge and I wasn't sure if I'd be able to make one but it turned out to be easier than I expected. It also had a interesting grid layout that I enjoyed replicating in CSS.

title: Manage landing page
description: With a simple slider created in the last challenge, I also wanted to try adding the dragging and infinite sliding to the slider in this challenge but it was simply out of my scope at that point so I stuck with the simple looping slider.

title: Job listings with filtering
description: This was my first time implementing content filtering in JS. If I knew some of the high order array methods, it'd have been a lot easier but I didn't so I just went with intuition as usual and I really enjoyed finishing it.

title: Interactive rating component
description: I remember being one of the first people to finish this challenge when it first came out. Even the founder of FEM, Matt Studdert liked my solution and I earned his follow :) I got a bit creative with how it revealed the results by adding a flip animation using my CSS animation knowledge. It was also my first project where I used SCSS.

title: Todo app
description: Back then, I wanted to do everything from scratch with vanilla JS without the use of libraries. It's also the same for the case of this drag-and-drop todo app. I had to watch a handful of tutorials on drag events and eventually got it to how I wanted it to be. Unfortunately, the draggin doesn't work on touch devices. That's something I'd like to revisit in the future.

title: Rock Paper Scissor
description: This one is still my all time favorite FEM challenge. I remember sharing this to all of my close friends to play after finsihing it. I tried to make it a SPA with only the use of vanilla JS for a seamless effect. I also added animations, sound effects and a lot more and it's also one of my proudest projects I did as a newbie. There're some issues like not removing eventListeners even after the elements are unmounted.

title: Launch countdown timer
description: Ah... this one! I love and hate this one. I really wanted to try making the flip animation of the timer with CSS and JS but I wasn't sure if I'd be able to so I tried it in my experimental files first and failed miserably. I just sat there all day trying to figure out how to sync the timing. I got frustrated after 2 days and left it as is for a few weeks. Then when I was pretty confident that I could do this, I started this challenge and it took me more than 2 days to get it exactly the way I wanted. I learned a lot about all the timing functions during this challenge.

title: IP address tracker
description: I didn't have the habit of reading Docs before this so it had me pretty confused because it involved working with two different APIs. But somehow I got it working by trying out different things. I'm also not very satisfied with how I got it so there's a high chance that I'll be revisiting this challenge in the future.

title: Sunny side agency landing page
description: For this challenge, I wanted to do it together with the community members in my Discord server so I engaged all of them to join me in creating this simple landing page, but only 2 of them joined and we shared our knowledge and solutions together.

title: Tip calculator React
description: When I started learning JS, this tip calculator challenge was my first JS project. So it'd only be right if this was also my first React project. I familiarize myself with the core React features in this challenge.

title: URL shortener
description: This project was for me to practice working with APIs in React and overall I learned a lot about some of the important hooks like useEffect and how to work with Async tasks in React.

title: Rest countries API
description: I initially planned to use Redux for this project since it was what I've been learning at that time but it seemed like an overkill so I just used the regular useState hook. I also used the react router dom for routing.

title: Expense chart component
description: I did this project to warm up my React knowledge since it had been a while since I last wrote React. But I ended up unfinished for some weeks late which I came up with a better solution than I orignally had and finished the challenge.

title: Interactive card detail form
description: This was a fairly new challenge when I did it and it basically includes a whole ton of form verifications. I went above and beyound for the verification process in this challenge which led it become a bit tedious but it was a great experience implementing little details for the verification. The styling of the cards was also a bit interesting.
